title: Unclaimed official s3 bucket of tendermint(tendermint-packages) which is used by many other blockchain companies in their code
vulnerability_information:
## Summary:
I have found an official unclaimed s3 bucket of tendermint i.e. http://tendermint-packages.s3-website-us-west-1.amazonaws.com/ which is also used by many other blockchain companies and developers .

## Steps To Reproduce:

1. Create a s3 bucket with name tendermint-packages and us west1 region
2. Make the settings and change it as a static website
3. You have successfully taken the s3 bucket .

## POC
1. Link of s3 bucket which shows i have claimed the bucket: http://tendermint-packages.s3-website-us-west-1.amazonaws.com/

{F1510071}

2. Pic of github which shows the companies that is using the unclaimed s3 bucket of tendermint:

{F1510070}

##Remedition

Check your internal code if there is any usage of unclaimed s3 bucket and claim the unclaimed s3 bucket(let me know when i should unclaim it from my side)

## Impact

An attacker can host its contents and malicious files on the official bucket of tendermint which can cause harm to the companies or developers using your bucket for package installation and etc. This bug has a severe impact if  it is used internally by tendermint and other companies.

Regards,
Gaurav Bhatia

activities.message: Who is using it? What is it used for?

Hey @robert-zaremba ,

##Who is using it? 
The companies and developers who are using the unclaimed s3 bucket are 
1. https://github.com/LambdaIM (https://github.com/LambdaIM/tendermint/blob/fc1c37c4ac9a93ac94029adabf27e37c34211e4f/tools/build/tendermint.list)
2. https://github.com/dojimanetwork
(https://github.com/dojimanetwork/tendermint/blob/0c9c3292c918617624f6f3fbcd95eceade18bcd5/tools/build/tendermint.list)
3. https://github.com/hashgard
(https://github.com/hashgard/tendermint/blob/a5a563e089e8f67181ae0df178d8d37ef5a5e89a/tools/build/tendermint.list)

and many more companies and developers are using it.
To know who all is using the bucket you can go to github.com and in search filed add **tendermint-packages amazonaws** and then you can see who all are using the official unclaimed s3 bucket of yours.

## What is it used for?

The official unclaimed s3 bucket of tendermint is used in .list files of the company.

The LIST file is a file created by APT, an Advanced Package Tool used to manage applications; holds a list of package sources that software can be downloaded from; contains information detailing the archive type indicating whether it contains binary or source packages.

The LIST file typically follows this format:
a. deb http://host/debian distribution section1 section2 section3
b. deb-src http://host/debian distribution section1 section2 section3

The first word of each line notifies the archive type:
           a. deb means that it holds a binary package.
           b. deb-src means that it holds a source package.
oh, seams that this could be use to do some social hacking style attack as well.

Hi @bhatiagaurav1211,

Thanks for writing up this security report. The scope of the bug bounty does not extend to forks of Tendermint. We hold no responsibility for these implementations. It also seems the repositories you specified haven't been modified in over a year so I don't think there is any need to make them aware of this bucket. In regards to Tendermint itself, it appears that the latest Tendermint version that references this AWS bucket is v0.32.14. The Tendermint team's policy is to provide security patches for the last two versions (in this case v0.34.x and v0.35.x) which this falls outside of. Being able to take over a bucket used for importing packages is nevertheless very dangerous but in this case, it looks like tendermint.list is being used for uploading releases to a Debian repository and isn't part of the tendermint binary itself so It's not clear to me what damage an attacker could actually cause.

Hey @cosmos

The companies i have added is to just show that companies are using and there are alot of companies and developers who are using it. Also it can be possible to get rce whoever install the package from the s3 bucket which makes it high. Also other people should know that there is rce bug whoever add the package from tendermint bucket. Also there can be many ompanies who are uploading packages from tendermint s3 bucket but the code is not public on github.

Also let me know if you need the poc video for rce?

Regards,
Gaurav Bhatia

Hey @cosmos,

You can create your own package from a malicious shell file and  upload it on the s3 bucket and run it. You can gain rce and command injection in it.

Hi Gaurav, 

Thanks for your patience, due to some staffing changes we have had a delay in triage and response, but we thank you for your disclosure and we are currently working on validating this and will provide an update once we have one, as well as a plan to disseminate the downstream dependency issues for other chains

Thank you again for your time and patience and we look forward to providing a remediation plan and will keep you updated!

Hi @bhatiagaurav1211 

As I noted I am still strapped for resourcing to address this, especially the realized impact(actual impact), exploitability, and the finer details such as bounties and CVE and disclosure.

As I said, I am still working this, so when I have an update I will immediately pass it on to you!

Thanks

Hi @bhatiagaurav1211
I have actually retrieved some validation, and this will echo @cmwaters message regarding supportability. While doing a dependency check as noted the downstream forks have mostly not been updated in an extended period of time.

We are working on codifying this within the product specifications but the plan for now is to make a notification via security advisory publication which I have drafted and will publish ASAP and other channels to disclose this was found, but direct notification to projects where we can't confirm that the projects are live is out of scope.

Vulnerabilities like this do in fact present a real threat but in this implementation it is not creating vulnerabilities we can actually manage or be impacted by, as you might have noted for the core product this exact package is archived and not in use, and not used in supported builds.


We thank you again for the submission and look forward to working together in the future!

Hey @jonws ,

As mentioned in my previous comment that the bucket officially of tendermint and due to this the other companies repo can be targeted by installing malicious package from .list file.

As per the law the main reason behind the attack on the company is due to tendermint and due to which there is chance of legal action against the tendermint due to no proper code checks and claim of S3 buckets.

Also if the same bucket used internally in tendermint can cause more harm to the company as they might be affected to it.

Also as the words said by @cmwaters that this might be out of scope due to version so of the bucket is out of version  you might should release a notice of this so that other users might know without being affected and also there is a option of denying users to claim the bucket rather than just removing the bucket which leads to the generation of new cyber attacks in this world of zero days.

I would request you for the consideration of this report as the impact here is much more critical and the cve I'd should be generated so that other users,companies can know about it.

Thanks and Regards.

Hi @bhatiagaurav1211 

We understand that this could be targeted for downstream users, of which the best practice if those chains are still active are to be subscribed to our security advisory publishing, this will serve as the notification. Regardless of us removing the bucket, which the Debian repository is NOT in use, will not remove it from those forks. The published public advisory will serve as notification

As for the laws, could you site which legal statures or codes in question? 

Regarding the verbiage on internal use, it is no longer in use so it has deemed not to be a threat internally, and certainly not a critical one, I will request a CVE but it will be informational as we've stated this is not considered a threat to the environment and the downstream forks, if any are active will be notified if they've subscribed to the security updates we provide.


With all this being said, I can not understate how important it is to have these conversations and continual work, while I am preparing processes to more efficiently and quickly address these bugs, I hope that you will also continue to contribute to the environment, we are better off with detailed contributions, such as this one.

Hey @jonws,
So, what further actions should we take regarding this matter?
